newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices slip with Treasuries.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS - prices slip with Treasuries.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond prices turned down from 3/8 to 3/4 of a point in late trade on Wednesday, tracking softer Treasury bonds, though traders said bid-wanted lists also exerted a bit of pressure.
"There were a lot of customers selling today, and a lot more bonds showed up in the marketplace," a trader said.

Bid-wanted lists were estimated at from $300 million to $400 million, and traders said there was sizable two-way flow, as institutions, who mostly appeared to be trying to sell long bonds, were willing to do business on a cash instead of a swap basis.
In contrast to municipal debt sold on Tuesday, several of the offerings brought to the market on Wednesday were repriced with higher yields.
"I guess people were scared deals wouldn't get done, so why not price them a little cheap?" a trader said, explaining the shift in the market's psychology.

For example, First Albany said it repriced and restrucutred New Hampshire's $64.1 million general obligation bond issue, raising yields in several maturities but leaving the top yield in 2016 unchanged at 5.35 percent.

And PaineWebber said it repriced Saint Luke's/Shawnee Mission Health System, Kan's $77.2 million bond issue, raising yields in several maturities but leaving the top yield in 2026 unchanged at 5.582 percent.
While the New York State Dormitory Authority restructured a $252 million sale of revenue bonds, the top yield was unchanged at 5.53 percent in 2015.

U.S. March Treasury bond futures, disappointed that the Federal Reserve did not buy coupons as many players had expected, slipped 21 ticks to 115-11/32. But the March municipal bond futures outperformed, only falling 11 ticks to 117-10/32.
As a result, the MOB spread between the two futures contracts fattened 10 ticks from levels seen on Tuesday to plus 63 ticks.

Actively traded issues included Metropolitan Pier & Exposition Authority Illinois Dedicated State Tax Revenue Refundings of June 2027, which pay a 5-1/4 percent coupon, and were bid at 5.58 percent NET, up three basis points.
And Alabama Water Pollution Control Authority Revolving Fund Loan of August 2020, which have a 5-1/2 percent coupon, were offered at 5.60 percent NET, down three basis points.
